utterances: That got Christie praise from conservatives nationally, along with his pledge to take on public employee unions, including police and firefighters, and to confront the teachers union.
And there was that proposed new rail tunnel from New Jersey into Manhattan that Christie killed.
At AEI yesterday, Christie said he wants President Obama to succeed, but he also was critical of Mr. Obama's push for things like high-speed rail and Internet - and electric cars.

Let me guarantee you something: If we don't fix the real big things, there are going to be no electric cars on the road, going to be no high-speed Internet access, or if there is, you're not going to be able to afford to get on it.
We're not going to be able to care about the niceties of life, the investments that Washington wants to continue to make.
That's not what we need to be talking about.
And to underscore his willingness to take on taboo topics, Christie said the Social Security retirement age needs to be raised.
Oh-ho, I just said it, and I'm still standing here.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You have to have a minimum GPA of 2.75 to be a member of ELITE, and Injagu says that rules a lot of black men out.
The ELITE black males on this campus are already overwhelmed with so many other opportunities because everybody is trying to snatch them up into their organizations.
At UNCG, the most recent statistics show that nearly 62 percent of black women finish a degree six years after starting.
By contrast, only 44 percent of black men do.
White men aren't doing much better.
About 46 percent of them graduate in six years.
Rod Wyatt is the associate director of athletics at UNCG.
He sits on a special subcommittee that's focusing on promoting the success of African-American men in particular.
The females on campus, they're going to take advantage of all of the services.
And if something is not right or they don't understand something or they have any problem, they seek out the assistance.
And, not only do they seek it out, they demand the assistance.
Wyatt says there's one group of men doing pretty well - athletes.
The NCAA reports the four-year graduation rate of black male athletes at UNCG is 67 percent.
For white male athletes, it's 83 percent.
One reason might be a class called University Studies 101.
We're proud to have you at UNCG, and we want you to hang with us, get that degree, go out and do some good things.
This is not a typical college class.
Students aren't reading Shakespeare or doing high-level math.
These students are learning how to be in college.
Has everybody done the survey in (unintelligible)?
All of the athletes at UNCG are required to take this class.
But most of the freshmen in University Studies 101 are taking it because they want to or it was recommended by an adviser.
My name is Courtney Jones.
I'm from Highpoint, North Carolina - furniture capital of the world.
I'm 18, and my major is currently elementary education.
Jones says she thought the course was going to be an easy A, but she ended up doing a lot of reading and writing and actually learned something about herself.
I need to be in complete silence when I study.
I can't study with the TV on, radio on or talking on the phone.
I'm not a very good multitasker, so I have to go somewhere quiet like the library and study.
And I procrastinate.
Education experts say it takes an extra effort to raise graduation rates.
Kevin Carey is research and policy manager of Education Sector, a Washington, D.C.
think tank.
He says today, the consequences are big for those who don't finish college.
All of the gains in our economy that have occurred over the last two or three decades really have all gone to people with a college education.
The job market doesn't give you partial credit for going to college for a while and not getting your degree.
You either graduate or you don't.
Statistics show more young, black men in America are in jail than in college.
And sophomore Yusef Bell(ph) knows most of those in college don't finish.
But he's not overwhelmed.
I think sometimes statistics can be crutch to people, so that - oh, you know, 70 percent of black people are not going to graduate, so why would I do it?
But sometimes it can be like a driving force for you to make sure that you don't fit that category.
So…
The women of ELITE say their friendship helps guarantee they'll cross the finish line.
Ashley Brown recently mailed off her last graduate school application.
So being surrounded by these people has made me into who I am today.
They inspire me to do more.
They inspire me to do better because it's like a healthy competition type deal.
We're all trying to do the best that we can do to, I guess, better UNCG - better ourselves in the end, eventually.
I hate to say it, but better the world.
The world.
Yeah.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's ideal.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Better the world, so…
For NPR News, I'm Leoneda Inge in Durham, North Carolina.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Rachel Martin.
A bombshell story in Rolling Stone magazine last month put the University of Virginia under scrutiny for its handling of campus sexual assault cases.
The emotional core of that story was a gang rape, a claim that a woman identified only as Jackie was assaulted by seven men at a fraternity party.
Then last week, another bombshell - Rolling Stone backed away from its reporting.
The managing editor wrote a statement saying the magazine has concerns about the piece and that there, quote, ""now appear to be discrepancies in Jackie's account.
Last month, NPR spoke with Emily Renda.
She handles sexual misconduct response and prevention at the University of Virginia.
She's also a graduate of the school and herself a victim of sexual assault.
We've called her again to get her take on this latest development.
Emily, first we should say you know the victim, the woman identified as Jackie.
She told you this story when you were with a campus support group.
Now, Rolling Stone has said that their trust in her was misplaced.
And I'm quoting there.
Do you doubt her story?
No, I don't.
I think that there are some larger complexities at play here.
There's a lot of good research, you know, citing Dr. David Lisak and Dr. Rebecca Campbell that suggest that traumatic memories are stored differently in the brain.
And so as a result, they're brought out by the brain different as well.
So through none of this process have I ever disbelieved Jackie.
Have I believed that details may change shape over time because of the nature of trauma?
Absolutely.
Have you spoken to her - Jackie - since the news broke?
It's something I've hidden for a long time, but I think you need to see the face of the women that you are impacting by this vote today.
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #1: Maybe it's a weeknight, you know?
Maybe people just getting off work, and maybe we'll see what happens.
Five, four, three, two, one.
Make some noise.
That's what we're - this thing's about - range rights.
You see, since the 1800s, our family's run livestock this same way.
Gleave says environmentalists are winning a battle to remove all livestock from Bureau of Land Management and Forest Service in the West.
That's who we're actually fighting with.
They've indoctrinated and got into this BLM and Forest Service.
A lot of them are right in the head positions now.
So you need to know that Stanton Gleave is like your typical Western rancher in one important way.
He doesn't own much land himself.
There's no room to run livestock in this tiny sliver of a valley, so he leases huge tracts of federal land that surround his place.

This was an arrangement that worked out pretty well for ranching families like his for generations, and the federal government was there to help - maintaining and building roads so ranchers could access their stock and to help with irrigation projects, building fences.
Look at this little valley right here.
When I was a kid, there was - let's see - one, two, three, four gas stations in it, two cafes, three cafes, a furniture store, a car dealership.
That was before the timber mills closed - most of the mines, too.
Then came President Clinton designating the massive Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument, and that forced the BLM to focus a lot more on the environment, recreation, not just cows.
The amount of public land available for grazing has been cut a lot - like, more than half since Gleave was a kid.
What would you do if you're losing everything you've got?
Would you stand and fight, or would you roll over and play dead, I guess?
And that's what (laughter)...
This is the kind of talk that's typical from a small, tightknit group of ranchers mainly clustered here in the remote Southwest.
They believe the Constitution doesn't allow for the federal government to control Western land.
Most are conservative, self-described devout Mormons who are allies with Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy.

The Bundy patriarch and several of his sons are now in jail, facing a litany of felony charges, including conspiracy and assault on federal officers for leading armed standoffs in Nevada in 2014 and earlier this year at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon.
The government is concerned about the potential for more conflicts mainly because of the death of one of this movement's leaders, LaVoy Finicum, in Oregon.
This eyewitness video shows Finicum in a tense standoff with the FBI and Oregon State Troopers at a roadblock in January.
